title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: outlines propose change hitop. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("jmgirard/hitop", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to hitop
text: Please note hitop project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with hitop
text: Thanks using hitop! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with hitop
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with hitop
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with hitop
text: efficient possible, development tidyverse packages tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Scoring the PID-5
text: full PID-5 220 items yields 5 domain scores 25 facet scores. can demonstrate ability score_pid5() function calculate scores using simulated (fake) data. also several validity scales developed full PID-5, including measures overreporting, inconsistent responding, positive impression management. can demonstrate ability validity_pid5() function calculate scores flag issues using simulated data. Note , data fake, expect lots validity issues.
code: data("sim_pid5")  score_pid5(sim_pid5, items = 1:220, append = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 100 × 25 #>    pid_anhedonia pid_suspiciousness pid_riskTaking pid_impulsivity #>            <dbl>              <dbl>          <dbl>           <dbl> #>  1          1.5               1.14           1.93             1.5  #>  2          1.38              1.71           1.21             2.17 #>  3          1.5               2.43           1.93             1.33 #>  4          2.25              1.29           1.57             1    #>  5          1.12              0.857          1.64             1.67 #>  6          1.5               2              1.21             2    #>  7          1.75              1.57           1.29             1.67 #>  8          1.38              1.57           1.57             1.5  #>  9          1.38              0.857          0.714            1.83 #> 10          1.38              1.57           1.64             1    #> # ℹ 90 more rows #> # ℹ 21 more variables: pid_eccentricity <dbl>, pid_distractibility <dbl>, #> #   pid_restrictedAffectivity <dbl>, pid_submissiveness <dbl>, #> #   pid_withdrawal <dbl>, pid_callousness <dbl>, #> #   pid_separationInsecurity <dbl>, pid_attentionSeeking <dbl>, #> #   pid_emotionalLability <dbl>, pid_depressivity <dbl>, pid_hostility <dbl>, #> #   pid_irresponsibility <dbl>, pid_rigidPerfectionism <dbl>, … #validity_pid5(sim_pid5, tibble = TRUE)

title: Scoring the PID-5
text: PID-5-FSF shorter version 100 items still yields domain facet scores. validity scales still calculable may fewer items psychometric properties , knowledge, examined FSF.
code: data("sim_pid5fsf")  score_pid5(sim_pid5fsf, items = 1:100, version = "FSF", append = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 100 × 25 #>    pid_suspiciousness pid_impulsivity pid_submissiveness pid_callousness #>                 <dbl>           <dbl>              <dbl>           <dbl> #>  1               2.5             2                  1.75            1.5  #>  2               2.25            1                  1.5             1.75 #>  3               0.75            1.5                1.75            1.5  #>  4               2.25            1.5                2.75            1.5  #>  5               1.25            2                  0.75            1.5  #>  6               1               1.75               1.25            1.75 #>  7               2               1.25               0.75            1.75 #>  8               1.25            2                  2.25            1.25 #>  9               1.25            1.25               0.5             2    #> 10               0.5             1.25               2               2    #> # ℹ 90 more rows #> # ℹ 21 more variables: pid_anhedonia <dbl>, pid_eccentricity <dbl>, #> #   pid_hostility <dbl>, pid_riskTaking <dbl>, pid_grandiosity <dbl>, #> #   pid_perceptualDysregulation <dbl>, pid_separationInsecurity <dbl>, #> #   pid_deceitfulness <dbl>, pid_perseveration <dbl>, #> #   pid_attentionSeeking <dbl>, pid_anxiousness <dbl>, pid_depressivity <dbl>, #> #   pid_withdrawal <dbl>, pid_restrictedAffectivity <dbl>, …  #validity_pid5fsf(sim_pid5fsf, tibble = TRUE)

title: Scoring the PID-5
text: can repeat process real data collected University Kansas (KU). fewer (still ) validity problems since real data. can also retain un-scored “ID” variables dataset.
code: data("ku_pid5fsf")  score_pid5(ku_pid5fsf, items = paste0("pid_", 1:100), version = "FSF", append = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 386 × 25 #>    pid_suspiciousness pid_impulsivity pid_submissiveness pid_callousness #>                 <dbl>           <dbl>              <dbl>           <dbl> #>  1               0               0                  0.5             0    #>  2               0.5             0.25               1.5             0.5  #>  3               1.75            1.75               2               1.75 #>  4               0.25            1                  0               0.25 #>  5               1.5             2.5                2               0.5  #>  6               0.75            0.75               0.75            0    #>  7               1.5             0.75               0.75            0.25 #>  8               0               0.25               1.25            0    #>  9               0               0                  2.25            0    #> 10               0.5             0.5                2.5             0.75 #> # ℹ 376 more rows #> # ℹ 21 more variables: pid_anhedonia <dbl>, pid_eccentricity <dbl>, #> #   pid_hostility <dbl>, pid_riskTaking <dbl>, pid_grandiosity <dbl>, #> #   pid_perceptualDysregulation <dbl>, pid_separationInsecurity <dbl>, #> #   pid_deceitfulness <dbl>, pid_perseveration <dbl>, #> #   pid_attentionSeeking <dbl>, pid_anxiousness <dbl>, pid_depressivity <dbl>, #> #   pid_withdrawal <dbl>, pid_restrictedAffectivity <dbl>, …  #validity_pid5fsf(ku_pid5fsf, id = "response_id", tibble = TRUE)

title: Scoring the PID-5
text: Finally, PID-5-BF brief version 25 items yields domain scores . validity scales calculable subset items.
code: data("sim_pid5bf") score_pid5(sim_pid5bf, items = 1:25, version = "BF", append = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 100 × 5 #>    pid_disinhibition pid_detachment pid_psychoticism pid_negativeAffectivity #>                <dbl>          <dbl>            <dbl>                   <dbl> #>  1               1.8            1.2              2.4                     1.8 #>  2               1.4            0.8              1                       2.2 #>  3               1.6            2.6              1.6                     1.4 #>  4               1.2            1.4              2.2                     1.6 #>  5               1.6            1.8              1.2                     2.2 #>  6               1.4            1.6              1.6                     1.8 #>  7               1.8            1.8              1                       2.2 #>  8               1.8            1.8              1.2                     1.2 #>  9               0.8            1.8              1                       0.4 #> 10               1.6            1                1.4                     1.4 #> # ℹ 90 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: pid_antagonism <dbl>

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jeffrey Girard. Author, maintainer.

title: Score the HiTOP-PRO Instrument — score_hitop_pro
text: Create data frame scores HiTOP-PRO scales.

title: Score the HiTOP-PRO Instrument — score_hitop_pro
code: score_hitop_pro(   data,   items,   srange = c(1, 4),   prefix = "pro_",   na.rm = TRUE,   calc_se = FALSE,   append = TRUE,   tibble = TRUE )

title: Score the HiTOP-PRO Instrument — score_hitop_pro
text: data data frame containing HiTOP-PRO items (numerically coded). items vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding 405 HiTOP-PRO items order. srange optional numeric vector specifying minimum maximum values HiTOP-PRO items, used reverse-coding. (default = c(1, 4)) prefix optional string add scale column name. prefix desired, set empty string "". (default = "pro_") na.rm optional logical indicating whether missing values ignored calculating scale scores. (default = TRUE) calc_se optional logical indicating whether calculate standard error scale score. (default = FALSE) append optional logical indicating whether new columns added end data input. (default = TRUE) tibble optional logical indicating whether output converted tibble::tibble(). (default = TRUE)

title: Score the HiTOP-PRO Instrument — score_hitop_pro
text: data frame containing scale scores standard errors (requested) original data columns (requested)

what: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
title: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
text: Calculate scale scores Personality Inventory DSM-5: full version (PID-5, 220 items), faceted short form version (PID-5-FSF, 100 items), brief form version (PID-5-BF, 25 items) item-level data.

title: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
code: score_pid5(   data,   items,   version = c("FULL", "FSF", "BF"),   srange = c(0, 3),   prefix = "pid_",   na.rm = TRUE,   calc_se = FALSE,   append = TRUE,   tibble = TRUE )

title: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
text: data data frame containing PID-5 items (numerically scored). items vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding PID items order. version string indicating version PID score: "FULL", "FSF", "BF". automatically capitalized. (default = "FULL") srange optional numeric vector specifying minimum maximum values items, used reverse-coding. (default = c(0, 3)) prefix optional string add scale column name. prefix desired, set empty string "". (default = "pro_") na.rm optional logical indicating whether missing values ignored calculating scale scores. (default = TRUE) calc_se optional logical indicating whether calculate standard error scale score. (default = FALSE) append optional logical indicating whether new columns added end data input. (default = TRUE) tibble optional logical indicating whether output converted tibble. (default = TRUE)

title: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
text: data frame containing scale scores standard errors (requested) original data columns (requested)

title: Score the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 — score_pid5
text: Krueger, R. F., Derringer, J., Markon, K. E., Watson, D., & Skodol, . E. (2012). Initial construction maladaptive personality trait model inventory DSM-5. Psychological Medicine, 42, 1879-1890. doi:10.1017/s0033291711002674 Anderson, J. L., Sellbom, M., & Salekin, R. T. (2016). Utility Personality Inventory DSM-5-Brief Form (PID-5-BF) measurement maladaptive personality psychopathology. Assessment, 25(5), 596–607. doi:10.1177/1073191116676889 Maples, J. L., Carter, N. T., , L. R., Crego, C., Gore, W. L., Samuel, D. B., Williamson, R. L., Lynam, D. R., Widiger, T. ., Markon, K. E., Krueger, R. F., & Miller, J. D. (2015). Testing whether DSM-5 personality disorder trait model can measured reduced set items: item response theory investigation personality inventory DSM-5. Psychological Assessment, 27(4), 1195–1210. doi:10.1037/pas0000120

what: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
text: Create data frame scores full PID-5 validity scales.

title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
code: validity_pid5(   data,   items,   scales = c("PNA", "INC", "ORS", "PRD", "SDTD"),   srange = c(0, 3),   append = TRUE,   tibble = TRUE )

title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
text: items optional vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding 220 PID-5 items order. set NULL (default), non-id columns assumed items order. scales optional character vector indicating following validity scales calculate: percent missing items ("PNA"), response inconsistency scale ("INC"), overreporting scale ("ORS"), positive impression management response distortion scale ("PRD"), social desirability-total denial scale ("SDTD"). See details interpretation guidance. srange optional numeric vector specifying minimum maximum values PID-5 items, used reverse-coding. (default = c(0, 3)) tibble optional logical indicating whether output converted tibble::tibble(). .data data frame containing PID-5 items (numerically scored). id optional vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding variables .data keep output. set NULL (default), columns retained.

title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
text: data frame containing id variables well requested scale scores.

title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
text: score 17 higher INC indicative inconsistent responding. score 3 higher ORS indicative overreporting. score 10 lower PRD indicative positive impression management (underreporting rather genuine responding) whereas score 21 higher PRD indicative genuine responding (rather positive impression management). score 11 lower SDTD indicative social desirability (rather defensiveness), whereas score 19 higher SDTD indicative defensiveness (rather social desirability).

title: Score the Full PID-5 Validity Scales — validity_pid5
text: Keeley, J. W., Webb, C., Peterson, D., Roussin, L., & Flanagan, E. H. (2016). Development Response Inconsistency Scale Personality Inventory DSM-5. Journal Personality Assessment, 98(4), 351-359. https://doi.org/10.1080/00223891.2016.1158719 Sellbom, M., Dhillon, S., & Bagby, R. M. (2018). Development validation overreporting scale Personality Inventory DSM-5 (PID-5). Psychological Assessment, 30(5), 582-593. https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0000507 Bagby, R. M., & Sellbom, M. (2018). Validity Clinical Utility Personality Inventory DSM–5 Response Inconsistency Scale. Journal Personality Assessment, 100(4), 398–405. https://doi.org/10.1080/00223891.2017.1420659 Williams, M. M., Rogers, R., Sharf, . J., & Ross, C. . (2019). Faking Good: Investigation Social Desirability Defensiveness Inpatient Sample Personality Disorder Traits. Journal Personality Assessment, 101(3), 253–263. https://doi.org/10.1080/00223891.2018.1455691

what: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
text: Create data frame scores PID-5 Faceted Short Form validity scales.

title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
code: validity_pid5fsf(   data,   items = NULL,   id = NULL,   scales = c("PNA", "INCS", "ORSS", "PRDS", "SDTDS"),   srange = c(0, 3),   tibble = FALSE )

title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
text: data data frame containing PID-5 items (numerically scored). items optional vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding 100 PID-5 items order. set NULL (default), non-id columns assumed items order. id optional vector column names (strings) numbers (integers) corresponding variables data keep output. set NULL (default), columns retained. scales optional character vector indicating following validity scales calculate: percent missing items ("PNA"), response inconsistency scale short form ("INCS"), -reporting scale short form ("ORSS"), positive impression management response distortion scale short form ("PRDS"), social desirability-total denial short form ("SDTDS"). See details interpretation guidance srange optional numeric vector specifying minimum maximum values PID-5 items, used reverse-coding. (default = c(0, 3)) tibble optional logical indicating whether output converted tibble::tibble().

title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
text: data frame containing id variables well requested scale scores.

title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
text: Scores 8 INC-S indicative inconsistent responding. Cut-scores ORS-S, PRD-S, SD-TD-S yet validated.

title: Score the PID-5-FSF Validity Scales — validity_pid5fsf
text: Lowmaster, S. E., Hartman, M. J., Zimmermann, J., Baldock, Z. C., & Kurtz, J. E. (2020). Validation Response Inconsistency Scale Personality Inventory DSM-5. Journal Personality Assessment, 102(6), 743–750. https://doi.org/10.1080/00223891.2019.1674320
